ECEAP Preschool is enrolling for the 2020-21 school year! ECEAP (Early Childhood Education and Assistance Program) is a free preschool program that serves children from low-income families or children who have other risk factors.

Children in the program this fall will start preschool remotely from home. We will provide learning packets, free meals, and supplies for children, including a laptop to borrow from the school district if needed. They will engage in online learning platforms, including Zoom meetings, until we can resume in the classroom. We will work alongside families and your to help your child learn and grow!

Contact Shannon Inton at intons@issaquah.wednet.edu or Kathy Wood at woodk@issaquah.wednet.edu to apply. Learn more at https://bit.ly/3hq4Pyw

Every summer, we need all ISD families to let us know if their students will be enrolled in our schools for the coming year by completing the Online Verification process. This important process helps us determine how many staff members we’ll need at each of our schools, and it gives you the chance to complete forms needed to start school.

Here’s what to do: Between Friday, August 7 and Thursday, August 13, please log on to Family Access (https://www01.nwrdc.wa-k12.net/scripts/cgiip.exe/WService=wissaqus71/fwemnu01.wand) and complete the process for each of your students. Look for the prompt asking you to complete the Enrollment Verification Process (EVP) for elementary students, Back-to-School Check-In (BTSCI) for middle school students, or Registration Student Verification Process (RSVP) for high school students. Thank you!

It’s Teacher Appreciation Week, and we’re highlighting several of our amazing teachers every day this week. Today, we meet Issaquah High’s Jordan Frost and the third-grade teachers at Briarwood Elementary.

Jordan Frost teaches psychology at Issaquah High School. IHS Principal Andrea McCormick says, “Mr. Frost put relationships first. He prioritizes student engagement and makes learning relevant to students' lives and personal goals.”

Briarwood’s third-grade teachers are Vicki Martinson, Michelle Peeples, Kelsey Dean, Christina van Heuven and Rin Mason. Briarwood Principal Steve Thatcher says, “We would like to highlight our 3rd grade team for diving into new online programs and mucking around with technology with a positive mindset and soaking everything in like sponges! We love hearing them talk about how they are collaborating and discussing how there are aspects to what they are doing now that could continue to be used when back in the classroom next year! Thank you for all your do to support your Bears every day!”

Today is National School Lunch Hero Day, and we want to celebrate the heroic food services staff in the Issaquah School District. The people who prepare and serve lunch and breakfast to our students have always been heroes, and never more so than now. Since the start of the current school closure, they have continued to provide much-needed meals to students throughout the district. They are the very definition of essential workers.

And it’s not just during times of crisis that our food services workers show their heroism. On the average day when school is in session, they serve about 7,800 meals per day! They adhere to strict nutrition standards, navigate student food allergies and offer caring service with a smile. Thank you to ALL of our School Lunch Heroes, including those who are working during the closure and those we’ll be thrilled to see again when our schools re-open!

It’s the final day of Classified School Employees Week, and let’s wrap it up by meeting the kitchen staff of Sunny Hills Elementary School: Donna Magnuson, Melanie Troutman, and Monica Pak. They recently played a big role in developing several scratch-made recipes that will be served at their school and other schools in the district (see a video about that at https://youtu.be/0fmBXfY1Efk). As we face the challenges of the current school closure, we feel it’s important to continue to recognize and celebrate the people whose hard work and dedication help make school happen. Thank you to all our classified staff!

It's Classified School Employees Week, and we’re recognizing a classified employee or group of employees each day this week. It is important to us in these difficult times to continue to recognize the hard work of the people who make school possible.

Today, meet landscape technician Dani Tronsen, who works at Sunset Elementary, Cougar Ridge Elementary and Pine Lake Middle School. She studied horticulture in college and ran a landscaping business before joining the district about a year ago.

“It’s nice to use my knowledge and expertise to make people proud of where their kids go to school,” Dani says. “If we can keep the school looking nice people want to be a part of it. And a lot of our work isn’t just making it look nice, but it’s also about safety.”

Dani often interacts with students who are curious about her work and uses it as an opportunity to teach them about plants, storm water, insects and other important topics.

Thank you to all our classified staff! It takes a lot of time, work and dedication to keep our schools running, and it couldn’t happen without you.

March 11, 2020

Dear ISD Community,

Following up on our earlier communication, the Issaquah School District is following Governor Jay Inslee’s directive to make contingency plans for possible school closures. While some of our neighboring districts have made a decision to close starting tomorrow, we are continuing to follow the advice of health officials. At this time, Public Health Seattle & King County continues to recommend that schools stay open. Therefore, All ISD Schools will be on a regular schedule tomorrow.

However, the Issaquah School District will close when guidance is given to the District by the State of Washington or Public Health of Seattle & King County or in the event we do not have sufficient staff to safely operate school. Please note: we have been informed that we will receive more direction from the Governor’s office on Thursday and will update the community as soon as we have additional information to share.

Sincerely,

The ISD Leadership Team

Schools across the district have celebrated Read Across America this week. Superintendent Ron Thiele visited Newcastle Elementary, where he read to first-graders in Mrs. Miller’s class. The Superintendent read the book “Imagine,” by Juan Felipe Herrera, which poetically tells of Herrera’s early life as the child of migrant farm workers, his love of language, and his eventual appointment to the post of U.S. Poet Laureate.

Read Across America is an annual nationwide celebration of reading that celebrates the diversity of America’s readers. All students benefit when they have access to books that reflect their own culture and experiences, and they develop a richer understanding of the world by reading about the cultures and experiences of others.

Happy reading, this week and every week!

When I had made the decision to become an FCS teacher myself I hoped and still do strive to create a similar experience with my students.”

Thank you Sarah!

For more information on the Issaquah School District’s CTE programs, visit buff.ly/2wr4eYp.

Don’t wait! Ballots are due by Tuesday, February 11.

January is National Mentoring Month, a time to recognize and celebrate the positive impact of adults who work one-on-one to guide and care for young people. Research shows that students who have a mentor are 55 percent more likely to enroll in college, 81 percent more likely to participate in extracurricular activities and 78 percent more likely to volunteer regularly.

In our own District, the VOICE Mentor Program has matched caring adult volunteers with students for more than 15 years. Last year, more than 300 mentors supported 466 students at all grade levels and at all ISD schools. Thank you, mentors!

Would you like to make a difference in the life of a child? There are still 165 ISD students waiting to be paired with a mentor. To volunteer and to learn more, visit https://www.issaquah.wednet.edu/academics/programs/voice or contact the VOICE program at voice@issaquah.wednet.edu or 425-837-7222.

An ISD teacher has played an important role in the naming of NASA’s next Mars rover, and now you can play a role too! Kristie Bennett, who teaches physics and astronomy at Skyline High, is a member of a committee that judged student submissions to name the Mars 2020 rover, which is planned to launch this summer. K-12 students from across the country submitted their name ideas, including a short essay explaining their choice. Mrs. Bennett and her fellow committee members judged the entries, and now you can vote on the finalists they selected. Go to mars.nasa.gov/mars2020/participate/name-the-rover/ to vote by 9 p.m. tonight.

Mrs. Bennett says this Mars mission creates great opportunities for learning in her classes, and she plans to teach a lot about Mars and space exploration in the coming months. The rover is scheduled to land in February 2021.

“This is a really cool mission because it’s all about life,” she said. “Has there been life on mars? Can we have successful habitation on Mars?”

Go vote on your favorite name now!

Issaquah City Council Approves Designation and Zoning for Schools at Providence Heights

The Issaquah City Council voted 5-2 at its January 21, 2020 regular meeting to approve land designation and zoning at Providence Heights as Community Facilities CF-F. We are thankful to the City Council and look forward to working with our municipal partners, the residents of Providence Point, and other neighboring communities to mitigate the impact as much as possible as we build these much needed schools.

The next step in that process will be for the District to submit a formal pre-application packet to the City of Issaquah, followed by a full application, community conferences, staff reviews, staff reports, and a recommendation by City staff to the City Council for a decision. According to the City, the length of time for reviewing and rendering a decision on the Master Site Plan will vary an estimated 4-8 months and depends upon staffing resources and the number of resubmittals ISD is required to submit. We will keep you informed as we work through the process over the coming months.

How would taxes be impacted by the ISD Renewal Levy? We are asking voters to authorize a levy of $49.85 million in 2021 and $54 million in 2022. This is about $6.7 million less than we are legally authorized to collect. This will allow us to maintain our current programs while remaining fiscally responsible and sensitive to the overall tax rate. Because previous bond debt is ending and because we’ve planned conservatively, the overall estimated total local school tax rate will go down from $3.46 to $3.25 per $1,000 of assessed property value in the first year and to $3.30 in the second year.

Election day is February 11. Make sure you're registered to vote and watch for your ballot later this month. Learn more about the levy at www.issaquah.wednet.edu/levy-2020

Our new Dual Language Immersion Program has had a great start this year! This is one of the many programs in our district funded by a voter-approved levy. That levy will expire this year, and in February voters will consider a replacement levy that would continue to help pay for this and many other valuable programs and services. Learn more at www.issaquah.wednet.edu/district/levy-2020.

Kindergarteners in the Dual Language program learn the same curriculum as other students in the district, but half the time they learn in English, and half the time they learn in Spanish.

Learning another language at a young age promotes academic growth and mental development, opens up opportunities later in life, and helps students understand and connect with different cultures.

Learn more about our Dual Language Immersion program at https://www.issaquah.wednet.edu/district/departments/elementary/DLIP

Students from ISD high schools spent the day looking toward their futures at the annual Great Careers Conference held at Bellevue College today.

Students had the chance to talk with people who work in a wide range of industries, including architecture and construction, education, health sciences, hospitality and tourism, law and public safety, marketing, information technology, and many more. Great Careers is all about giving students the chance to learn about careers they can pursue through apprenticeships, trade schools, or two-year programs.

The event also included a presentation by Nathan Graham, a senior at Gibson Ek High School, who spoke to his fellow students about his research into the benefits of trade school and other alternatives to four-year degree programs. Job opportunities in many career fields that don’t require a four-year degree are growing rapidly and projected to keep growing, Graham said, and attending a trade program can help avoid student loan debt.

Pictured are LHS sports medicine teacher and athletic trainer Morten Orren and school nurse Anissa Pascale, who, along with athletic director Danielle Zelinski, are instrumental in promoting safety for Liberty's athletes.

Issaquah Middle School math teacher Traci Brewster got a delightful surprise this morning: She received the Heroes in the Classroom Award from Symetra and the Seattle Seahawks at a school-wide assembly.

The prize comes with tickets and field-passes for an upcoming Seahawks game, a Seahawks jersey and $2,000 for her classroom. Seahawks player Malik Turner helped present the award and talked to the students about his experience with a teacher who changed his life when he was in school.

“Ms. Traci Brewster is a teacher that gives more time and passion to our community than any other teacher that I know, or honestly have ever known in my 18 years as an educator,” said IMS Principal Carrie Reckling, who nominated her for the award. “She is the first one in our parking lot most days at 5 a.m., and then is consistently here until 8 or 9 in the evening.”

Principal Reckling also talked about Ms. Brewster's commitment to her students' success and her refusal to give up on any student.

Congratulations, Ms. Brewster, and thank you for making a difference for so many students!

To succeed in school and in life children need good mental health and the ability to get along with others. That's why, supported by local levies, the Issaquah School District has added more school counselors, licensed mental health counselors, and coaches who work with students and staff to promote healthy behavior and emotional awareness.

Each of these roles works together, along with teachers, administrators and other school staff, to support all students. They teach positive behaviors and social skills, and work directly with students in need. All of our schools now have access to a school-based licensed mental health counselor, who can help students dealing with issues such as depression or anxiety and can connect families to mental health professionals in the community.

Learn more about our school-based mental health vounselors at https://www.issaquah.wednet.edu/family/counseling-services/SBHC and learn more about our Positive Behavior and Social Emotional Support program at https://www.issaquah.wednet.edu/academics/programs/pbses

We’ve made significant upgrades to school safety measures in the past couple years. All of our schools are now equipped with keycard access and have either a secure vestibule system or an intercom and camera system, which allows staff to keep track of who enters and exits our buildings. These safety upgrades are among the many improvements possible in our schools because of voter-approved levies and bonds.

We love having community members in our schools! Thank you to everyone for adapting to these changes and working with us to protect the safety of students, staff and visitors in our schools.

Attention drivers: Always stop for a school bus when its red lights are flashing and its stop paddle is out! We recently partnered with Verra Mobility to install bus paddle cameras on 30 of our buses. The cameras record drivers who do not stop for buses picking up or dropping off students. Drivers have their license plate information sent directly to law enforcement and are subject to a $419 fine.

“We are so pleased to have these bus paddle cameras on our fleet,” said Director of Safety and Security, Dave Montalvo. “Our goal is to keep students safe by ensuring motorists obey the law.” District staff and families are excited about this latest enhancement to student safety.

It's National School Bus Safety Week, a great time to review safe school bus behaviors with your family. Check out these tips from the National Association for Pupil Transportation: https://www.napt.org/files/NSBSW/Bus%20Stop%20Safety%20Tips-2016update.pdf

More than 1,300 teachers and other certificated staff gathered this week at Issaquah High School to get ready for the new school year at the annual ISD Conference.

Elementary staff attended on Wednesday, and secondary staff on Thursday. The days included a keynote presentation by Dr. Richard Villa, an expert on inclusive education, who spoke about the importance of designing schools where every student belongs and receives an education that builds on their unique strengths.

Teachers chose to from among dozens of sessions about a wide range of educational topics designed to help them grow as educators and help their students succeed.

Groundbreaking News! New ISD Elementary School to Open Fall 2020.

City of Sammamish officials joined with the Issaquah School District’s Board of Directors and administrators for a ceremonial groundbreaking on the land upon which the District’s newest elementary school will be constructed. A group of students at Gibson Ek High have been working to make gaming and coding more accessible to people with disabilities, and they were featured last month in Microsoft Education's video series "What's New in EDU." Check out that video:

The students worked with Gibson Ek advisor Robin Lowell to create a world within the game Minecraft to help students and teachers teach and learn how to use adaptive technology. They also worked with Code Jumper, a coding language that allows kids who are blind or visually impaired to code using physical hardware components.

The Gibson Ek group calls themselves the Accessibility Pirates, a riff on the name of Microsoft's accessibility team, the Accessibility Ninjas.

Lowell says her group of "pirates" took to the project with real excitement: "They all love gaming, and once they started learning about accessibility, it gave them the opportunity to be really creative. Not only do they get to work on Minecraft, which they all love, but they also get to find out great ways for other kids to play."

Last night, volunteers from the Issaquah Schools Foundation's VOICE mentor program gathered to celebrate another year of serving students. At the ISF's annual mentor appreciation dinner, long-time mentors were recognized for putting in five or more years, and all mentors picked up donated books to give to the students they work with.

VOICE mentors work one-on-one with individual students on a weekly basis at schools throughout the district. They help with whatever the student needs, whether it's academic support, help managing their emotions, or just a chance to express their thoughts to a listening adult.

This year, VOICE had about 400 mentors, who were matched with 458 students, gave out about 400 books, and met with students more than 3,300 times!

Interested in volunteering? Learn more at http://isfdn.org/our-purpose/connecting-students-to-their-future/voice-mentors/

Have you got five minutes and feel like maybe crying a bit? Then check out "One in 13 Million," the national award-winning film by Issaquah High student Isobel Grudin! (https://vimeo.com/335777126) Isobel's film received an Award of Excellence in this year's National PTA Reflections competition. She was one of only three high school students in the country to receive the award for film. This year's Reflections theme was "Heroes Around Me." Here's what Isobel had to say about her film:

“Becoming a hero does not happen overnight. It is not a job title or something one can vacation from. From the first time a child lays its eyes upon their parents, they see heroes. From then on, for the rest of their lives, parents are striving to be those heroes. When a child has a single parent, that parent works much harder to be their hero. Single parents often go unnoticed for the work they do and the hardships they face. There are thirteen million single parents in the US that selflessly become heroes for their children."

It's National School Nurse Day, so let's take a moment to acknowledge the 21 registered nurses working our schools! School nurses play a crucial role in keeping our students healthy and safe.

Nurses help improve attendance at school by promoting health and disease prevention and management. They save time for teachers, principals and other staff by addressing health concerns, and they help schools stay up-to-date with state and federal laws. They're ready and able to support any ISD student.

Here are just a few of the many tasks our nurses perform:
• Care for students with chronic health conditions such as diabetes, epilepsy, heart conditions and asthma
• Write annual student care plans
• Provide vision and hearing screenings
• Plan for and respond to emergencies
• Track communicable diseases
• Comfort sick students

Thank you, ISD nurses!

Engu Fontama, a senior at Issaquah High School, has been chosen to receive a National Certificate of Accomplishment from the Princeton Prize in Race Relations. Engu is the founder and president of the Consciousness and Racial Empowerment (CARE) Club at IHS. The National Certificate of Accomplishment is awarded to only four students in the Seattle region.

“The committee thinks the world of your work with CARE,” Adam Stuhlfaut, chair of the Princeton Price in Race Relations’ Seattle Region, wrote to Engu. “You are a leader and an innovator in your approach to race relations in your high school and your school district. Wherever you go after high school will be extremely fortunate to have you working in their community in the area of race relations.”

CARE's goal is to help foster a more racially conscious and inclusive culture at Issaquah High and to support all students of color.

Engu Fontama, a senior at Issaquah High School, has been chosen to receive a National Certificate of Accomplishment from the Princeton Prize in Race Relations. Engu is the founder and president of the Consciousness and Racial Empowerment (CARE) Club at IHS. The National Certificate of Accomplishment is awarded to only four students in the Seattle region.

“The committee thinks the world of your work with CARE,” Adam Stuhlfaut, chair of the Princeton Price in Race Relations’ Seattle Region, wrote to Engu. “You are a leader and an innovator in your approach to race relations in your high school and your school district. Wherever you go after high school will be extremely fortunate to have you working in their community in the area of race relations.”

CARE's goal is to help foster a more racially conscious and inclusive culture at Issaquah High and to support all students of color.

Engu plans to attend Stanford University after graduating this year.
